2 Easy Ways to Register a DLL (with Pictures) - wikiHow 
 Home Random Browse Articles Notifications Add to This Page Add Tip Easy Ways to Help Approve Questions Review Tech Feedback Fix Spelling More Things to Try...   
 Log in / Sign up   
 Desktop Site   
 Community Tested How to Register a DLL   
 This wikiHow teaches you how to register a DLL file on a Windows computer. Registering a DLL can fix startup issues for some programs. Keep in mind that you cannot register DLLs that came pre-installed on your Windows computer, as these DLLs are vital to Windows' operation. 
 Steps Edit 
 Part One of Two: Finding the DLL Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a2\/Register-a-DLL-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a2\/Register-a-DLL-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 1 
 Open Start
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760} 
.  Click the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cf\/Register-a-DLL-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-2-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cf\/Register-a-DLL-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-2-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 2 
 Open File Explorer
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/0d\/Windowsstartexplorer.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/0d\/Windowsstartexplorer.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760} 
.  Click the folder-shaped icon in the lower-left side of the Start window.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7e\/Register-a-DLL-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-3-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7e\/Register-a-DLL-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-3-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 3 
 Click  This PC .  It's a computer-shaped icon on the left side of the window.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/58\/Register-a-DLL-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-4-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/58\/Register-a-DLL-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-4-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 4 
 Double-click your hard drive's icon.  This drive-shaped icon is below the "Devices and drives" heading. It will usually have  (C:)  in its title.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4a\/Register-a-DLL-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-5-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4a\/Register-a-DLL-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-5-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 5 
 Double-click the "Windows" folder.  It's near the bottom of the window, though you may first need to scroll down to see it.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/81\/Register-a-DLL-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-6-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/81\/Register-a-DLL-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-6-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 6 
 Scroll down and double-click the "SysWOW64" folder.  This folder is near the bottom of the page. Most of your computer's program-installed DLL files are stored here. [1] 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c5\/Register-a-DLL-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-7-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c5\/Register-a-DLL-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-7-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 7 
 Verify that the DLL is in the folder.  If you know the DLL's exact name, you can type it into the search bar in the upper-right side of the folder.
 If you don't know the DLL's full name, you can click the  Type  column heading and then scroll down to locate the DLL. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d0\/Register-a-DLL-Step-8.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-8.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d0\/Register-a-DLL-Step-8.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 8 
 Move the DLL from a different folder.  If you can't find your DLL in the "SysWOW64" folder, it's in the "System32" folder instead. To move it, do the following:
 Click the "Back" arrow  ← 
 Double-click the "System32" folder. 
 Find the DLL and select it. 
 Press  Ctrl + C  to copy the DLL. 
 Click the "SysWOW64" folder on the left side of the window. You may have to scroll down here. 
 Click a blank space in the folder, then press  Ctrl + V  to paste in the DLL. 
 Advertisement 
 Part Two of Two: Using Command Prompt Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/37\/Register-a-DLL-Step-9.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-9.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/37\/Register-a-DLL-Step-9.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-9.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 1 
 Open Start
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760} 
.  Click the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e3\/Register-a-DLL-Step-10.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e3\/Register-a-DLL-Step-10.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 2 
 Type  command prompt  into Start.  Doing so will search for the Command Prompt program.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/Register-a-DLL-Step-11.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-11.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/Register-a-DLL-Step-11.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-11.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 3 
 Right-click
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/6\/66\/Windowscmd1.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/6\/66\/Windowscmd1.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383.33333333333,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":633.33333333333} 
Command Prompt.  It's at the top of the Start window. A drop-down menu will appear.
 If your mouse or trackpad doesn't have right and left buttons, use two fingers to tap on the trackpad (or press the trackpad's button), or press the right side of the button, to simulate a right-click. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/32\/Register-a-DLL-Step-12.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-12.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/32\/Register-a-DLL-Step-12.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-12.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 4 
 Click  Run as administrator .  It's in the drop-down menu.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a4\/Register-a-DLL-Step-13.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-13.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a4\/Register-a-DLL-Step-13.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-13.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 5 
 Click  Yes  when prompted.  Doing so will open Command Prompt with Administrator privileges.
 If you aren't an administrator on your computer, you will not be able to register your DLL. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f1\/Register-a-DLL-Step-14.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-14.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f1\/Register-a-DLL-Step-14.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-14.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 6 
 Switch to the "SysWOW64" directory.  Type  cd \Windows\SysWOW64  into Command Prompt, then press  ↵  Enter .
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/21\/Register-a-DLL-Step-15.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-15.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/21\/Register-a-DLL-Step-15.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-15.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 7 
 Enter the "register" command.  Type  regsvr32  into Command Prompt, then type a space.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/74\/Register-a-DLL-Step-16.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-16.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/74\/Register-a-DLL-Step-16.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-16.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 8 
 Enter your DLL's name.  In all lowercase letters, type in the name of your DLL followed by  .dll .
 For example: to register a DLL named "12345.dll", you would type  regsvr32 12345.dll  into Command Prompt. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/49\/Register-a-DLL-Step-17.jpg\/v4-460px-Register-a-DLL-Step-17.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/49\/Register-a-DLL-Step-17.jpg\/v4-760px-Register-a-DLL-Step-17.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 9 
 Press  ↵  Enter .  This will run the command and register your DLL file. You should receive a pop-up window with "[DLL name]...succeeded" written in it.
 Advertisement

 What do I do if the "register" button will not work? 
								Answered by  
								 War_lizard   
 Refresh the page or restart the computer.

 Tips Edit 
 You can also unregister a DLL by entering  regsvr32 /u [dll name].dll  into Command Prompt. This is helpful if you want to delete a DLL, as every registered DLL is considered "read-only" and thus impossible to delete without unregistering first. 
 0 
 Helpful? 
   0 
 Add 
 Warnings Edit 
 DLLs are essential for Windows to run properly. Accidentally deleting or changing a system DLL, while nearly impossible, will most likely harm your computer.
